title: Mike Diessner
text:
I am a second-year PhD student in Computing at Newcastle University in the United Kingdom. Within the university, I am part of the Cloud Computing for Big Data CDT and the Fluid Dynamics Lab.

My research focuses on computer emulators and optimisation of physical experiments and computer simulations. I am also developing NUBO, a transparent Bayesian optimisation package in Python, with the aim of making the optimisation of expensive-to-evaluate black box functions accessible to researcher from all disciplines. An open-source version will be available in early April 2023.

title: Mike Diessner
text:

title: Mike Diessner
text:
Publications

2023
Joe O’Connor, Mike Diessner, Kevin Wilson, Richard D. Whalley, Andrew Wynn, and Sylvain Laizet. “Optimisation and Analysis of Streamwise-Varying Wall-Normal Blowing in a Turbulent Boundary Layer,” Flow, Turbulence and Combustion, 2023.


2022
Mike Diessner, Joe O’Connor, Andrew Wynn, Sylvain Laizet, Yu Guan, Kevin Wilson, and Richard D. Whalley. “Investigating Bayesian optimization for expensive-to-evaluate black box functions: Application in fluid dynamics,” Frontiers in Applied Mathematics and Statistics, 2022.
Matthew L. Thomas, Gavin Shaddick, David Topping, Karyn Morrissey, Thomas J. Brannan, Mike Diessner, Ruth C. E. Bowyer, Stefan Siegert, Hugh Coe, James Evans, Fernando Benitez-Paez, and James V. Zidek. “A Data Integration Approach to Estimating Personal Exposures to Air Pollution,” 2022 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data), 2022.

title: Mike Diessner
text:
Presentations

2022
European Drag Reduction and Flow Control Meeting, “On the development of a Bayesian optimisation framework for turbulent drag reduction,” Conservatoire National des Arts et Métiers, Paris, France.

title: Mike Diessner
text:
Software

simplelhs: Simple implementation of Latin hypercube sampling to generate space filling designs (Python).
Install: PyPI Source: GitHub
benchfuncs: Selection of benchmark functions to test optimisation algorithms (Python).
Source: GitHub
NUBO: Bayesian optimisation framework to solve expenisve-to-evaluate black box functions (Python). [In development]

title: Mike Diessner
text:
Teaching
I worked as a teaching assistant on the following courses:
Computing Foundations of Data Science
Postgraduate-level module teaching the fundamentals of programming in Python.
Data Management and Exploratory Data Analysis
Postgraduate-level module teaching students all necessary tools to analyse data with R.
Statistics for Empirical Psychology
Undergraduate-level module teaching the fundamentals of statistics to psychology students (linear regression, mixed-effects model, hypothesis testing, etc.).

title: Mike Diessner
text:
Education


PhD in Computing
Newcastle University
Advisors: Richard D. Whalley and Kevin Wilson


Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom
June 2021 - August 2024



Investigation of Bayesian optimisation for expensive-to-evaluate black box functions.
Application to computer simulations and physical experiments in engineering to find optimal active blowing strategies to maximise drag reduction.
Award of a full studentship including stipend, tuition, research costs (equipment, publishing fees, conference fees, etc.), and travel and lodging costs for national and international conferences (approx. £89,000).





PGDip in Computing
Newcastle University


Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom
September 2020 - May 2021






MSc in Statistics
University of Exeter


Exeter, United Kingdom
September 2019 - August 2020



Thesis: “Using Agent-based Modelling to Estimate Personal Exposure to PM2.5 in Devon”.
Developed model was later used in the paper “A Data Integration Approach to Estimating Personal Exposures to Air Pollution”.
Awards:

Dean’s Commedation: For performance at the top end of the First Class range.
MSc Academic Award: For the best overall performance on a postgraduate Mathematics programme in 2020 (£100).






BSc in Economics
University of Bonn


Bonn, Germany
September 2014 - February 2018



Thesis: “Universal basic income and its effects on the labour market in Germany”.
